channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: Russian Liberal Who Aided Post-Soviet Overhaul Comes Under Attack
item.description: Anti-Western hard-liners in the Kremlin have gone after allies of Anatoly B. Chubais, who has largely retreated from public life and runs a company that uses public funds.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE
item.media:description: Anatoly B. Chubais bringing flowers to the spot in Moscow where Boris Y. Nemtsov, the Russian opposition leader, was fatally shot in February.

item.title: A.P.J. Abdul Kalam, Ex-President Who Pushed a Nuclear India, Dies at 83
item.description: Nicknamed “the Missile Man of India,” Dr. Kalam was one of his country’s most beloved figures for his role in advancing its nuclear program.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY
item.media:description: A.P.J. Kalam was the president of India from 2002 to 2007.

item.title: F.B.I. Emphasizes Speed as ISIS Exhorts Individuals to Attack
item.description: The bureau’s strategy of patiently tracking suspected terror sympathizers has given way to a faster-moving approach amid fears about attacks on U.S. soil.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: MATT APUZZO and MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT
item.media:description: Law enforcement officials in June after Usaamah Abdullah Rahim, a man who had been in contact with the Islamic State online, was shot in Boston as F.B.I. agents tried to apprehend him.

item.title: Dutee Chand, Female Sprinter With High Testosterone Level, Wins Right to Compete
item.description: An arbitration panel in Switzerland ruled that it was not necessary for I.A.A.F., track and field’s governing body, to exclude female athletes with enhanced testosterone levels.
item.dc:creator: JOHN BRANCH
item.media:credit: Graham Crouch for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dutee Chand did not follow recommendations that she take hormone-suppressing drugs or have surgery to limit her amount of testosterone. "I want to remain who I am and compete again," she said.

item.title: Thailand’s Low Ranking in Human Trafficking Report Could Hamper Trade Deal
item.description: The State Department renewed Thailand’s ranking on the lowest tier for making little effort to end trafficking, a move that could harm President Obama’s Trans-Pacific Partnership.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG and JOE COCHRANE
item.media:description: Human remains were retrieved on May 2 from a mass grave in Thailand's southern Songkhla Province near the border with Malaysia.

item.title: Obama Calls Ethiopian Government ‘Democratically Elected’
item.description: President Obama’s remarks came two months after the governing party and its allies won every seat in Parliament in elections condemned as a sham by human rights groups.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and JACEY FORTIN

item.title: Greece Made Preparations to Exit Euro
item.description: The contingency plans for a possible exit from the euro began before the current leaders came to power, the former Greek finance minister said.
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING and NIKI KITSANTONIS
item.media:description: Yanis Varoufakis, Greece’s former finance minister, wrote in a blog post Monday that the country would have “been remiss had it made no attempt to draw up contingency plans.”

item.title: Obama, in Ethiopia, Addresses South Sudan Conflict
item.description: He convened a meeting to try to forge peace in the new country, the birth of which four years ago was the capstone of his Africa policy.
item.dc:creator: PETER BAKER and MARC SANTORA
item.media:description: President Obama in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, on Monday, where he will convene a meeting to try to forge a peace in South Sudan.

item.title: Beirut Journal: Lebanese Seethe as Stinking Garbage Piles Grow in Beirut and Beyond
item.description: Residents cited the failure of the Lebanese government to ensure adequate trash collection as proof of a dysfunctional leadership.
item.dc:creator: BEN HUBBARD
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: A restaurant worker took two bags of trash to add to a giant pile of garbage left uncollected for a week outside a bar named Floyd the Dog in Beirut.

item.title: Ending the Abuse of Laws, Workers and the Environment at Sea
item.description: Labor, human rights and environmental abuses are widespread largely because the oceans are so sprawling, but officials say there are ways to police the high seas.
item.dc:creator: IAN URBINA
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dock workers sort through fish at a port in Ranong, Thailand. Technology exists that can better track fish as they move from bait to plate.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Chen Zhonglin on ‘Picking Quarrels’ Online
item.description: Mr. Chen, a law professor at Chongqing University, discussed the meaning of “rule of law” and the uses and abuses of the charge of “picking quarrels and provoking trouble.”
item.dc:creator: ADAM WU
item.media:description: Chen Zhonglin, law professor at Chongqing University.

item.title: Chinese Shares Tumble Again
item.description: The main Shanghai index slid 8.5 percent, its biggest one-day decline in eight years, abruptly ending a nearly three-week lull in the market rout.
item.dc:creator: NEIL GOUGH
item.media:description: The plunge in China's stock market was displayed on Monday at a brokerage house in Hangzhou.

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Rights Advocates, and a Monk, Oppose Beijing’s Winter Olympics Bid
item.description: Opponents of the effort by China are citing a widening crackdown on rights defense lawyers, political activists and ethnic minorities.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: CHERIE CHAN and ANDREW JACOBS
item.media:description: Golog Jigme, an exiled Tibetan monk, has urged that Beijing not be awarded the 2022 Winter Games.

item.title: At Least 20 Are Killed in Attack at Afghan Wedding Party
item.description: The authorities suspected that a local dispute had caused the shooting in a village in northern Afghanistan.
item.dc:creator: JOSEPH GOLDSTEIN

item.title: Turkey and U.S. Plan to Create Syria ‘Safe Zone’ Free of ISIS
item.description: American warplanes, Turkish forces and anti-ISIS rebels within Syria would join to clear a section along the border, creating what the Turks call a “safe zone” for refugees.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD, MICHAEL R. GORDON and ERIC SCHMITT
item.media:description: The Incirlik Air Base in southern Turkey. Turkey and the United States agreed on a plan that would create what officials are calling an Islamic State-free zone, which the Turks say could also be a “safe zone” for displaced Syrians.

item.title: Observatory: Farming Had an Earlier Start, a Study Says
item.description: Farming may have originated 23,000 years ago, thousands of years earlier than previously thought, according to seeds researchers found at an ancient site.
item.dc:creator: SINDYA N. BHANOO

item.title: Inquiry Into Litvinenko Poisoning Is Delayed After Russian Fails to Testify
item.description: A lawyer said the man was “not in a position to give oral evidence” because he felt bound by confidentiality agreements related to a separate, Russian inquiry into the ex-K.G.B. officer’s death.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Dmitri V. Kovtun in Moscow in April.

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: For Hissène Habré, a Trial by Refusal
item.description: The former president of Chad scuttled his trial for mass crimes by turning the principles of human rights defenders against them.
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.dc:creator: THIERRY CRUVELLIER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: How the Greek Deal Could Destroy the Euro
item.description: By treating Grexit as a viable option, Europe has made a future French, or even German, exit more likely.
item.dc:creator: SHAHIN VALLÉE

item.title: Palestinian, 18, Dies While Trying to Evade Arrest, Israeli Police Say
item.description: The Israeli police spokesman, Micky Rosenfeld, said the man had been shot as he ran across rooftops in the Kalandia refugee camp.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID
item.media:description: Mourners buried Mohammad Atta Lafi Abu Latifa in Kalandia refugee camp, near the West Bank city of Ramallah, on Monday.
